w:r.w:t: This chapter introduces properties and their concept of configuring various aspects of the Virtual Data System. For an in-depth reference of properties and settings, please refer to the property reference documentations in

Properties are a Java concept to configure general behavior of programs. Properties are usually employed, if a specific behavior is required over many executions. You can think of properties as environment variables for Java – indeed, the usage and applicability of properties mirrors those of environment variables.
Like environment variables, Java properties are mappings from a key to a value. As properties are ubiquitous in a Java application, it can query the setting of a property at any time.

Java properties, unlike environment variables, permit a hierarchical structure to their keys. A period (.) separates the tiers of the hierarchy. All properties concerning the VDS start with the prefix "
", and properties concerning Euryale start with the prefix "
Properties are case-sensitive. Both, the key and the value, must use proper case, unless the property reference guide specifically permits case independence.

Sets of properties are maintained in textual files. To change properties, simply open the property file in your favorite text editor. The format of property files permits multiple different specifications according to your preference.
Empty lines are ignored. Comment lines start with an
(#) or exclamation point (!) as first character. Comment lines are also ignored. Lines that are neither empty nor a comment should hold a key-value pair.

The key of a key-value pair may be hierarchically structured, using a period (.) to separate the tiers. Each component of a key behaves like an identifier in a procedural programming language: It starts with a letter, and may contain letter, digits or the underscore thereafter.
Keys and values are either separated by one or more linear white-space characters (horizontal tabulator or regular space), or by the first equals (=) or colon (:) character.
contains more details on the acceptable file format, like Unicode encoding, multi-line values and empty values.
The VDS added the feature of variable property values to plain Java properties. It is possible to specify the value of one property referencing one or more values from other known properties.
curly braces refer to the value of the named property. For instance,
means that the value depends on the value of the
any noted additions. You can use this notation to refer to other
There are a couple of things to keep in mind when using these variable values:
The substitutions are only possible for property values, not property keys.

Substitutions can only refer to properties that are known at the point of processing. Specifically, this means that a value in the system properties cannot refer to a value in the user properties. The empty string substitutes unknown property references.
Nesting is not permitted. If a substituted value itself contains a reference, that reference will not be resolved.
There is a priority handling to properties. By default, the average user does not need to worry about the priorities. However, it is good to know the details of when which
property applies, and how one property is able to overwrite another.
Property definitions in the system property file, found in
, have the lowest priority. These properties are expected to be s
et up by the submit host'
The properties defined in the user
While we say $HOME, technically, it is the account's home directory in the system's user directory. This is important when running with a substituted user identity.
have higher priority. These can overwrite sett
properties. A set of sensible property values to set on a production system is shown below.
Command-line properties have the highest priority.
The -D prefix introduces a command-line property.
arguments must be the first arguments to any command. Command-line properties are useful for

The VDS is set up in a way that the value of the environment variable
to any VDS tool. This is done automatically without user interaction. While it is possible to overwrite the location of the VDS tools using a command-line property, we cannot recommend doing so.

property provides the basis for a GNU directory layout. GNU conventions distinguish between platform-independent sharable and platform-specific local, as well as mutable and rarely changing data directories.
The VDS properties for the GNU directory structure use the value of the
property as their base directory, and append the appropriate directory according to above table. Each can be overwritten using command-line properties, but such is rarely necessary.
The system properties are associated with the property key

The user properties are associated with the property key
file ignored. For testing purposes, it is sometimes beneficial to provide a user property value of
are a Java system properties provided by the Java Virtual Machine. Other useful system properties include
While Pegasus follows the VDS property layout, Euryale does not. Euryale only uses one property file

Because Euryale is driven by multiple background processes, all configurations, including those usually better put on a command-line, must reside in the Euryale's property file. Changes to the property file will take effect immediately with newly started instances of the Euryale background processes.
